large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary (safe, jump).
Begin Circle Time by introducing the book and asking: How can you stay safe at home?
Read for enjoyment and entertainment, noticing vocabulary in context
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share ideas and feelings.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Identify and solve problems.
Use top-to-bottom and left-to-right directionality when writing.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to talk about pictures that show ways to keep safe.
Guide children to ask and answer questions about things people can do to stay safe.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find of characters in the book who are doing things that are safe?
Can you pretend to be a dinosaur? How would you move?
How would you sort the dinosaurs into different groups?
Can you write about one way you can stay safe?
Can you build a dinosaur? What materials would you use?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word safe? Can you think of another word that starts with that sound?
Can you build a safe place for a dinosaur to live? What kind of place will it be?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about the Mind Builder develop empathy, and introduce vocabulary (empathy, understand).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe ?
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show background knowledge; Share ideas and feelings.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use sentences with multiple phrases.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Identify and solve problems.
Use information to categorize.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children talk about feelings and how they can identify different feelings in others.
Guide children to look at facial expressions and posture to sort photos into groups that show happy and unhappy people.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show me pictures of characters who are happy? Can you find characters who are sad?
Can you act out how to keep someone safe?
Can you put three characters in the book in order from biggest to smallest?
Have you ever made someone feel better when they were sad?
Can you draw a picture of a happy person?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the end of the word dinosaur? Can you think of another word that starts with that letter?
Can you build a place where you would take a friend to cheer them up?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? by Jane Yolen, illustrated by Mark Teague. Text copyright © 2015 by Jane Yolen. Illustrations copyright © 2015 by Mark Teague. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share comprehension skill Listen and Remember and introduce vocabulary (climb, helmet).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the Big Book, and asking the guiding question: What are some ways to stay safe outside?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show background knowledge; Share ideas and feelings.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use subject-verb agreement; Use sentences with multiple phrases.
Persist in tasks.
Use information to categorize; Use information to compare and contrast.
Remove word from a compound word.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children look at pictures and determine whether the safe activity is inside or outside.
Talk about what makes each activity safe.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find pictures of children doing things outside while being safe? How do you know they are being safe?
Pretend you are climbing the biggest tree in the world.
What could you use to measure your head?
Write how you could stay safe in a new place.
Can you draw a picture of a friend wearing a helmet?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word run? Can you write it?
Build a tall tower. What materials would you use?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? by Jane Yolen, illustrated by Mark Teague. Text copyright © 2015 by Jane Yolen. Illustrations copyright © 2015 by Mark Teague. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed
Big Book: How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about health and safety and to try out different ways to jump.
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? and Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show background knowledge; Share ideas and feelings.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use sentences with multiple phrases.
Identify and solve problems.
Follow classroom rules and routines.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.
Use information to compare and contrast.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children look at pictures and determine whether the activity is safe or not safe.
Talk about what makes each activity safe or not safe.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How can you stay safe when you are riding a bike?
Pretend to be one of the froggies in the Big Chart. What will you wear?
Can you use counters to count the number of froggies you see in each picture in the Big Chart?
Can you write about how you can stay safer on the playground?
What would be a safe place for people to jump? Can you draw it?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word jump? Can you write it?
Can you build two climbing walls? What materials would you use?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? by Jane Yolen, illustrated by Mark Teague. Text copyright © 2015 by Jane Yolen. Illustrations copyright © 2015 by Mark Teague. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to play a game to reinforce listening skills and to introduce vocabulary (spot, hike).
Begin Story Time by revisiting How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? and asking: What did you learn from the dinosaurs about staying safe?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show background knowledge; Share ideas and feelings.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use subject-verb agreement; Use sentences with multiple phrases.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Identify and solve problems.
Use top-to-bottom and left-to-right directionality when writing.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Why is it important to keep safe while you play?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find pictures of children helping each other stay safe?
Imagine you are in a car ride. What can you do to stay safe?
Use counters to count how many children are wearing blue.
Can you write about something that you do at home to stay safe?
Can you draw a picture of a friend wearing a seatbelt?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word hike? Can you think of another word that makes that sound?
Can you create a place for you and a friend to play?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? by Jane Yolen, illustrated by Mark Teague. Text copyright © 2015 by Jane Yolen. Illustrations copyright © 2015 by Mark Teague. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Provide appropriate information about various situations.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Use appropriate directionality when writing (top to bottom, left to right).
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people and actions.
Use sentences with more than one phrase.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Initiate problem-solving strategies with help from adults as needed.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular and irregular past tense, personal pronouns, and possessives, and subject-verb agreement.
Use sentences with more than one phrase.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Delete a word from a compound word.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use sentences with more than one phrase.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Follow classroom rules and routines with occasional reminders from teacher.
Demonstrate coordination and balance in isolation.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular and irregular past tense, personal pronouns, and possessives, and subject-verb agreement.
Use sentences with more than one phrase.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seeks adult help when necessary.
Use appropriate directionality when writing (top to bottom, left to right).
Demonstrate coordination and balance in isolation.
